 not give any commitment that its prices would not rise in the near future.
Private firms which the Labor Party has spoken to have also admitted that they would be likely to take advantage of an increase in the fees charged by the AGS and likewise increase their fees. As a result, as I said earlier, we are concerned that there are cost pressures in the system—pressures that either are transitional or relate to matters I have already mentioned. This will essentially mean that the savings the government anticipates could be illusory and the cost increases of the AGS could be reflected in increased costs to government.
We are also concerned in respect of legal service directions. As I mentioned earlier, the government's policy has recognised that there is a considerable public interest in the Attorney-General retaining some control over the conduct of litigation services to the Commonwealth. The good name of the Commonwealth could quite often be degraded if even some lawyers were to conduct sharp practices in the Commonwealth's name. To this end the Commonwealth has introduced a complex system of directives that the Attorney can issue for litigation matters generally and in relation to specific cases. These directives would be enforceable by contractual remedies only and would, of course, be subject to breaches of the directives coming to the Attorney's attention.
This is a wide ranging task. It is a task which covers the breadth of government. The office established to perform such a task was originally staffed by only three people. Given that the Commonwealth manages some 15,000 pieces of litigation per year, it was and continues to be our concern that this function could not be adequately performed with the resources allocated. Now the government has said that it will apply six staff to this function. However, it is fair to say that our concerns are real and they still remain in respect of administration of the directions under this part of the government's proposal.
Our concern is also heightened by the fact that the office is also expected to coordinate Commonwealth legal services to ensure consistency of advice. In essence, model 
 litigant rules will become meaningless if there is inadequate means to enforce them. Our firm opinion is that the resources applied by government to this particular task will mean inadequate resourcing.
As I said earlier, the Public Service terms and conditions are of concern to us. While the AGS must have greater flexibility in its future staffing arrangements, this should not be done at the expense of the rights of employees. All current AGS staff must have the right to retain employment with the APS or to an adequate redundancy package if they do not wish to be employed by the new AGS. So we will be moving amendments in the committee stage to protect these terms and conditions. The amendments will give the AGS employees the option of electing to retain their current APS terms and conditions. The government is looking only upward in terms of flexibility as to terms and conditions and it should have no problem supporting these amendments.
In conclusion, can I say that, given the very real interest in the Commonwealth's retaining control over the government related litigation services, we believe that the model proposed by the government does not adequately protect that public interest. Accordingly, we submit that, firstly, the bill should be opposed unless the government does agree to provide an independent mechanism to review the impact of the reforms and to recommend the supplementation of departmental and agency resources to take into account the increase in the price to be paid for legal services. Secondly, we believe the government should agree to increase the resources of the Office of Legal Services Coordination to ensure it can meet the full range of functions intended for it. Thirdly, we believe the government should provide appropriate transitional arrangements for the staff of the AGS.
We have approached the Attorney and his office over some period of time with these concerns—some couple of years now. We have also sought to raise these concerns with the government through third parties which have an interest in seeing the bill passed. As of the current date, unfortunately the government and the Attorney have shown little 
 interest in responding to these concerns. We have to ask ourselves whether the government is really committed to this policy or whether it is grandstanding for some of its big corporate mates. We do want to see this issue resolved. As I said, we will be moving amendments to try to target the three most immediate and pressing concerns that we have in respect of this legislation. I indicate now that, at the appropriate time, I will be moving the amendments circulated in my name.

name: Cooney, Sen Barney
text:
—As Senator Bolkus has said, the Judiciary Amendment Bill 1998  is directed at placing the Australian Government Solicitor on a basis that it has been moving towards, I suppose, for some time now—that is, on the basis of being a separate legal entity, a little like the private enterprise firms. When I say `a little like' I mean that advisedly because the Australian Government Solicitor now has to go into competition with private firms, some of very big size indeed.
The work they go into competition for is very much government work. They cannot go into competition for work outside the government or the semi-government sector. This means that the firms that they are going to be contesting against have available to them a very wide range of work indeed—not only government work but non-government work, the work that they have been pursuing for years. That gives them economy of scale. It gives them economy of personnel, if you like, because they can have personnel in all fields of law and they can employ that personnel in all sorts of places amongst all sorts of clients whereas the Australian Government Solicitor is going to be confined very closely indeed. It seems to me that it is a misnomer to say that is competition. It is certainly not fair competition in any event. I want to come to that again a little later, but there is one other matter I want to deal with before I come to that. Under part VIIIC of this bill the Attorney-General may issue directions. Proposed section 55ZF, `Attorney-General may issue directions', says:
(1) 	 The Attorney-General may issue directions (Legal Services Directions ): 

	 (a)	 that are to apply generally to Commonwealth legal work; or
	 (b)	 that are to apply to Commonwealth legal work being performed, or to be performed, in relation to a particular matter.
And it goes on. But the issue I want to raise is whether or not those directions should be disallowable instruments. The attorney has said that, insofar as they are legislative in nature, they should be disallowable. He has had some correspondence with the Scrutiny of Bills Committee and, as usual, has been very frank and very full in his explanation to that committee. While I am on my feet in this matter, I should perhaps note that, as far as the Scrutiny of Bills Committee is concerned, the Attorney-General has been always very prompt in his answers and very forthcoming.
On this occasion, he says yes, if these directions are of a proper nature, they should be disallowable, but the problem is that at the moment there is no way by which they can be made disallowable because we really need to have the legislative instruments bill made into an act before we can take a proper course with such directions as the Attorney-General makes which are appropriate to be disallowed. It would be proper, I think, not to bring this part of this legislation in until the legislative instruments bill is made into an act or, pending that, until some amendment has been made to the Acts Interpretation Act.
No doubt all this sounds very technical, but it does raise issues of some importance. The importance is that parliament should not be blocked out from its duty and its function of looking at subordinate legislation that it should look at and it should not be stopped from scrutinising the executive when that is appropriate. As the legislation now stands, together with the statutes that are in operation, a gap will be left in the ability of parliament to carry out its function if this legislation goes through and the legislative instruments bill does not and while there is no amendment to other legislation. So the position is that the Attorney agrees, `Yes, in certain circumstances these directions I give should be disallowed. Yes, there is no legislation presently in operation which would allow that to happen but, nevertheless, the bill should go on.' 
I now want to return to the issue of the Australian Government Solicitor. I notice it is almost 10 to 10, but perhaps I can read this bit from the second reading speech and then make some comments on it. It states:
The bill—
that is, the Judiciary Amendment Bill—
will establish the Australian Government Solicitor, the AGS, as a statutory corporation that will operate as a government business enterprises. It will strengthen the position of the AGS in the market for Commonwealth legal work with private sector law firms.
I have already said something about this, but this is another example of a very topsy-turvy approach to how services ought to be provided—a very strange approach, may I say, to getting good service from the Australian Government Solicitor. That has been with the Attorney-General's Department over the years that I have known it and has been a most distinguished body. It has been run by distinguished secretaries and been staffed by distinguished people.
Debate interrupted.

name: Gibbs, Sen Brenda
text:
—I rise this evening to remind the Senate of the ongoing situation at the Gordonstone mine, near Emerald in Central Queensland. The Gordonstone picket line is now into its 17th month, making this the longest ever picket in Australian coalmining history.
The conflict stems from the unfair dismissal of 312 miners by the multinational giant Arco back in October 1997. In February 1998, the AIRC ordered Arco to compensate for the unfair dismissals, additionally instructing the company to give preference to former workers in the recruiting of their new work force. Having failed to de-unionise Gordonstone, Arco packed up and left, selling out to another multinational giant, Rio Tinto.
In December, Rio Tinto commenced recruitment for Gordonstone in secret, employing 23 
 workers under a non-union agreement. The agreement overrides all existing obligations of any employer at the Gordonstone mine and was ratified on 2 February. The AIRC has no discretion when ratifying agreements under coalition legislation and union submissions were not even allowed at the hearing. Rio Tinto had intended to employ up to 200 workers under this new certified agreement.
Workers who had fought for 17 long months to try to regain their jobs were not about to take this latest attack lying down. The Construction, Forestry, Mining and Energy Union went to the Federal Court in a bid to have Rio Tinto joined as a party to the proceedings being brought against the former owners, Arco. This would compel Rio Tinto to employ the workers unfairly dismissed back in 1997. The continuing dispute will come before the Federal Court in April.
As the industrial dispute at Gordonstone continues, I think it is of the utmost importance that we do not forget about the personal situations of the sacked workers. These are people who had worked hard for Arco and were rewarded with nothing but unfair dismissal for their service. There was never any evidence that these workers had been lazy or unproductive; on the contrary, they were among the most productive by international standards. Just months before their dismissal, Arco had erected a statue to the Gordonstone miners describing them as `the best miners in the world' after they had broken a succession of international production records. These were undoubtedly hardworking people. Suddenly, in October 1997, they were sacked en masse, and just before Christmas.
Since the closure of Gordonstone, the town of Emerald has experienced considerable economic and social upheaval. In a recent interview with the Courier-Mail, Emerald Chamber of Commerce president, Tony Webster, spoke of the impact the dismissals have had on local businesses. Mr Webster said that many businesses were struggling and more had actually sold up and moved on as a direct result of the ongoing dispute. Since October 1997, Emerald's population has declined from around 10,500 to 8,500 people. Those who have been able to secure work 
 elsewhere have done so, but many former Arco workers remain in Emerald and are suffering severe financial hardship. These people have maintained the picket line as they continue to fight for the jobs that were unfairly taken from them.
The Courier-Mail article of 22 February also outlined the considerable emotional distress suffered by the dismissed workers and their families during their 17-month ordeal. In the article, local Salvation Army Captain Stephen Metcher spoke of a number of attempted suicides by former Gordonstone miners and their children. These people are not rabblerousers. They are people who just want a fair go after having been unfairly sacked by their employer. They do not want more money or better conditions; they just want to go back to their jobs the way they were before.
Now Rio Tinto has sought to capitalise on their weakened condition after such a long dispute by seeking to implement a non-union agreement with substandard conditions. This multinational has sought to divide the community by offering an unfair agreement to individuals who are desperate to go back to work. It has replaced decent working people with scabs, it is as simple as that. Rio Tinto has a ready-made work force at its disposal in the form of the dismissed workers. Instead of getting on with the job at hand, it has sought to crush the union by instituting enterprise agreements that undermine prevailing standards and conditions. It has effectively put the boot into the workers after Arco already had them down. This government has abandoned the people of Emerald in favour of multinational corporations.
—What? The Beattie government?
—No, your government. The decisions of the AIRC were disregarded by Arco, who blatantly refused to re-employ the dismissed workers when the commission instructed them to do so. Now Rio Tinto is showing a similar flagrant disregard for Australian industrial relations provisions. The AIRC has the authority under Australian law to determine the outcome of such disputes, and our government should not condone the 
 actions of foreigners who seek to undermine that authority. However, we currently have a government that actually seeks to do away with the AIRC altogether. Who is to defend the rights of Australian workers if this government is determined to undermine the authority of the AIRC and take the side of multinational business interests?
This government has even sought to crush the union that has provided workers with their strongest support. An article in the Sydney Morning Herald on 24 February outlined secret government plans to undermine the CFMEU. Employers who fall foul of the CFMEU will receive extra time to complete government projects, according to a leaked document from the defence minister, Mr Moore. The article claimed the leaked document was `a further indication of the government's determination to reduce the CFMEU's power'. Without the AIRC and unions, workers would be left at the mercy of these multinational corporations which have no regard for their employees and their families. This is supposed to be a government democratically elected to represent the Australian people. It could more accurately be described as being representative of the interests of big business and big money as far as industrial relations are concerned.
On Saturday, 27 February, I attended a huge march and rally with the Gordonstone miners in Emerald. Over 1,000 people were in attendance at Emerald to offer their support to the miners and their families. Speeches mingled with the laughter of children at play nearby as the traditional Aussie Saturday afternoon barbecue got under way. That is what this dispute is really about—families. The miners have received constant support from their wives and children, who have also had to endure this long running stand-off with the foreign multinationals. These people are fighting to secure a livelihood for their families and that is what it all comes down to. The multinationals will always want to make more money, but all the Gordonstone miners want is a fair go for their families. I think it is a disgrace that a democratically elected government has left them to make this stand alone. 
In conclusion, I would just like to say that, even though a lot of the miners have moved on and work in other areas, those who are left on the picket line have told me that, because of their involvement in the mining industry and the union, they are black-listed by other mine owners. They are totally black-listed because they are seen as agitators when they are merely there in a peaceful picket.
One guy said to me, `I might never work again. If I go and look for a job in another mine, my resume says I have worked seven years in the mining industry, but I might as well put on my resume that I have been in gaol for seven years.' An employer may say, `Okay, I will give you a go,' but they will not give him a go because he has been working at Gordonstone and has been active in supporting himself, his family and his fellow workmates.
